The term crypto is referred to all types of technologies that have evolved from blockchain technology. They are all based on cryptography, a branch of mathematics used to securely store and transfer information. Crypto exists independently of any centralized authority, and its value is determined by the market forces of supply and demand. 

It is mostly used as a currency to transfer value between participants. Crypto transactions are recorded on a public ledger called a blockchain, and secured using complex cryptography and distributed computing power. It can also offer other use cases such as NFTs, smart contracts or any other kind of data storage with the ability to provide unique and authentic data. 

Crypto technology is powered by users who “mine” for cryptocurrencies using computing power to solve complex mathematical problems. This in turn generates tokens that can be exchanged for goods and services. Because crypto transactions are encrypted and stored on a blockchain ledger, they are secure and immutable. 

They also provide an additional layer of security compared to traditional payment systems because they use public and private keys to confirm transactions. Crypto is becoming increasingly popular due to its ability to provide a secure, anonymous and fast way to transfer money around the world, often with low fees. 

Crypto also offers greater control over one’s money by eliminating monetary middle men, such as banks or credit companies, from the equation. As a result, there is no need for lengthy registration processes or paperwork when transferring funds. Besides the use as a currency, the crypto sector also provides NFTs as another major use case. NFTs can provide the advantage for any kind of digital data and many new markets could evolve from this ability.
